text.p: The Polisario Front, seeking an independent state in the Western Sahara, named Bachir Mustapha Sayed as foreign minister in their self-proclaimed government, the Algerian official news agency APS said on Saturday.
Mustapha Sayed, who was the Front representative to the United Nations Mission for the Referendum in Western Sahara, was replaced by former aide M'Hamed Khaddad.

Malainine Sadik, outgoing foreign minister, became adviser to Polisario Front leader Mohamed Abdelaziz, who is president of the self-proclaimed Democratic Arab Sahraoui Republic, which is recognised by more than 75 governments.

Al Khalil Si M'hamed was named interior minister, replacing Salem Lebsir, who became Abdelaziz's protocol chief. Mohamed Salem Ould Salek, Abdelaziz's senior adviser, replaced Sid M'hamed as education minister, said APS.
A U.N.-sponsored referendum, originally scheduled for January 1992, is stalled by differences over who should vote between Polisario and Morocco, which controls most of the former Spanish colony.
The two sides have observed a ceasefire since 1991.
